aquatic.word_example: So, unless this reef was subject to the intermittent eruptions of a geyser, the Governor Higginson had fair and honest dealings with some  aquatic mammal, until then unknown, that could spurt from its blowholes waterspouts mixed with air and steam.
aquatic.word_definition: operating or living or growing in water

daunting.word_example: Yet if some saw it purely as a scientific problem to be solved, more practical people, especially in America and England, were determined to purge the ocean of this  daunting monster, to insure the safety of transoceanic travel.

phenomenon.word_example: This animal, this monster, this natural  phenomenon that had puzzled the whole scientific world, that had muddled and misled the minds of seamen in both hemispheres, was, there could be no escaping it, an even more astonishing  phenomenon—a  phenomenon made by the hand of man.

colossal.word_example: So only two possible solutions to the question were left, creating two very distinct groups of supporters: on one side, those favoring a monster of  colossal strength; on the other, those favoring an "underwater boat" of tremendous motor power.
colossal.word_definition: so great in size or force or extent as to elicit awe

ilk.word_example: Consequently, the feats of krakens or other monsters of that  ilk must be relegated to the realm of fiction.

hoax.word_example: The tabloids found it a fine opportunity for hatching all sorts of  hoaxes.

fantasy.word_example: And so the monster surfaced again, despite the endless witticisms heaped on it by the popular press, and the human imagination soon got caught up in the most ridiculous ichthyological  fantasies.
fantasy.word_definition: something many people believe that is false

fabulous.word_example: Even if I had discovered that some  fabulous, mythological creature really existed, it wouldn't have given me such a terrific mental jolt.

existence.word_example: No naturalist, neither Cuvier nor Lacépède, neither Professor Dumeril nor Professor de Quatrefages, would have accepted the  existence of such a monster sight unseen—specifically, unseen by their own scientific eyes.
existence.word_definition: the state or fact of being

carapace.word_example: But this hard substance could have been a bony  carapace, like those that covered some prehistoric animals, and I might have left it at that and classified this monster among such amphibious reptiles as turtles or alligators.
carapace.word_definition: hard outer covering or case of certain organisms

bandit.word_example: The first one of these  bandits who lays a hand on me—
bandit.word_definition: an outlaw who is (usually) a member of a group

dreadful.word_example: And if it has their power to electrocute, it's surely the most  dreadful animal ever conceived by our Creator.

constitution.word_example: "Note well, my fine Canadian," I went on, "if such an animal exists, if it lives deep in the ocean, if it frequents the liquid strata located miles beneath the surface of the water, it needs to have a  constitution so solid, it defies all comparison."
constitution.word_definition: the way in which someone or something is composed

rascal.word_example: "That  rascal must be covered with six-inch armor plate!"

brute.word_example: As for me, with your permission I'll go perch on the bobstays under the bowsprit, and if we can get within a harpoon length, I'll harpoon the  brute.
brute.word_definition: a living organism characterized by voluntary movement

cannibal.word_example: All that's lacking is for them to be  cannibals! I wouldn't be surprised if they were, but believe you me, they won't eat me without my kicking up a protest!
cannibal.word_definition: a person who eats human flesh

immense.word_example: We were stretched out on the back of some kind of underwater boat that, as far as I could judge, boasted the shape of an  immense steel fish.
immense.word_definition: unusually great in size or amount or extent or scope

unearthly.word_example: The human mind enjoys impressive visions of  unearthly creatures.
unearthly.word_definition: suggesting the operation of supernatural influences

infernal.word_example: "And $500.00 to the man who can pierce that  infernal beast!"

contraption.word_example: "does this  contraption contain some sort of locomotive mechanism, and a crew to run it?"
contraption.word_definition: a device or control that is very useful for a particular job

insensitive.word_example: We could still hope that the animal would tire out and not be as  insensitive to exhaustion as our steam engines.

savage.word_example: These people are about as hospitable as the  savages of New Caledonia!
savage.word_definition: a member of an uncivilized people

apparition.word_example: The relevant data on this  apparition, as recorded in various logbooks, agreed pretty closely as to the structure of the object or creature in question, its unprecedented speed of movement, its startling locomotive power, and the unique vitality with which it seemed to be gifted.

negotiate.word_example: Many of our sailors swore that the monster couldn't  negotiate this passageway simply because "he's too big for it!"
negotiate.word_definition: succeed in passing through, around, or over

host.word_example: In these mysterious marine sanctuaries, I envisioned  hosts of unknown animals, and this underwater boat seemed to be a blood relation of theirs: living, breathing, just as fearsome.

rogue.word_example: We speak French, English, German, and Latin to these  rogues, and neither of them has the decency to even answer back!

antic.word_example: We were finally in the area of the monster's latest  antics!
antic.word_definition: a ludicrous or grotesque act done for fun and amusement

prodigious.word_example: opinion had crystallized as to the nature of this phenomenon, and the public accepted without argument the existence of a  prodigious creature that had nothing in common with the fabled sea serpent.
prodigious.word_definition: great in size, force, extent, or degree

marine.word_example: "Therefore," I wrote, "after examining these different hypotheses one by one, we are forced, every other supposition having been refuted, to accept the existence of an extremely powerful  marine animal.
marine.word_definition: of or relating to the sea

elusive.word_example: The monster again became an islet, rock, or reef, but a runaway reef, unfixed and  elusive.

stupendous.word_example: In those newspapers short of copy, you saw the reappearance of every gigantic imaginary creature, from "Moby Dick," that dreadful white whale from the High Arctic regions, to the  stupendous kraken whose tentacles could entwine a 500–ton craft and drag it into the ocean depths.
stupendous.word_definition: so great in size, force, or extent as to elicit awe

dissect.word_example: To answer them called for  dissecting this unknown monster; to  dissect it called for catching it; to catch it called for harpooning it—which was Ned Land's business; to harpoon it called for sighting it—which was the crew's business; and to sight it called for encountering it—which was a chancy business.

titanic.word_example: Couldn't the heart of the ocean hide the last–remaining varieties of these  titanic species, for whom years are centuries and centuries millennia?

outrageous.word_example: This  outrageous animal had to shoulder responsibility for all derelict vessels, whose numbers are unfortunately considerable, since out of those 3,000 ships whose losses are recorded annually at the marine insurance bureau, the figure for steam or sailing ships supposedly lost with all hands, in the absence of any news, amounts to at least 200!
outrageous.word_definition: greatly exceeding bounds of reason or moderation

unpredictable.word_example: These beasts can be quite  unpredictable!

leviathan.word_example: He believed in it as certain pious women believe in the  leviathan from the Book of Job—out of faith, not reason.
leviathan.word_definition: monstrous sea creature symbolizing evil in the Old Testament

notorious.word_example: You see, my friend, it's an issue of the monster, the  notorious narwhale.

gigantic.word_example: Nothing remotely resembling a  gigantic narwhale, or an underwater islet, or a derelict shipwreck, or a runaway reef, or anything the least bit unearthly!
gigantic.word_definition: so exceedingly large or extensive as to suggest a giant

cetacean.word_example: If it was a  cetacean, it exceeded in bulk any whale previously classified by science.
cetacean.word_definition: large aquatic carnivorous mammal with fin-like forelimbs

girth.word_example: Its  girth was more difficult to judge, but all in all, the animal seemed to be wonderfully proportioned in all three dimensions.
girth.word_definition: the distance around a person's body

\"Twenty Thousand Leagues Under the Sea,.list_detailed_description: Translated by F.P. Walter, these words from the narrator created by Jules Verne will guide you through an underwater tour of the world.

\"What Maisie Knew,\" Vocabulary from In.list_brief_description: What can a young child know about the actions and desires of adults? Find out through the words of the omniscient narrator created by Henry James. Here are link...

ingenious.word_example: She had the knowledge that on a certain occasion which every day brought nearer her mother would be at the door to take her away, and this would have darkened all the days if the  ingenious Moddle hadn't written on a paper in very big easy words ever so many pleasures that she would enjoy at the other house.

voluble.word_example: Miss Overmore, then also in the vestibule, but of course in the other one, had been thoroughly audible and  voluble; her protest had rung out bravely and she had declared that something—her pupil didn't know exactly what—was a regular wicked shame.
voluble.word_definition: marked by a ready flow of speech

certitude.word_example: Everything that had happened when she was really little was dormant, everything but the positive  certitude, bequeathed from afar by Moddle, that the natural way for a child to have her parents was separate and successive, like her mutton and her pudding or her bath and her nap.

consciousness.word_example: And with this Sir Claude's eyes rested on the little girl in a way that seemed to her to mask her mother's attitude with the  consciousness of his own.
consciousness.word_definition: an alert cognitive state in which you are aware of yourself

subtlety.word_example: It was a contradiction that if Ida had now a fancy for waiving the rights she had originally been so hot about her late husband shouldn't jump at the monopoly for which he had also in the first instance so fiercely fought; but when Maisie, with a  subtlety beyond her years, sounded this new ground her main success was in hearing her mother more freshly abused.
subtlety.word_definition: a fine difference in meaning, opinion, or attitude

confound.word_example: The child was provided for, but the new arrangement was inevitably  confounding to a young intelligence intensely aware that something had happened which must matter a good deal and looking anxiously out for the effects of so great a cause.

extravagance.word_example: Beale, under this frolic menace, took nothing back at all; he was indeed apparently on the point of repeating his  extravagance, but Miss Overmore instructed her little charge that she was not to listen to his bad jokes: she was to understand that a lady couldn't stay with a gentleman that way without some awfully proper reason.
extravagance.word_definition: the quality of exceeding the appropriate limits of decorum

inconsistent.word_example: If she was her father's wife she was not her own governess, and if her presence had had formerly to be made regular by the theory of a humble function she was now on a footing that dispensed with all theories and was  inconsistent with all servitude.

penetrate.word_example: Her very silence became after this one of the largest elements of Maisie's consciousness; it proved a warm and habitable air, into which the child  penetrated further than she dared ever to mention to her companions.
penetrate.word_definition: become clear or enter one's consciousness or emotions

inimitable.word_example: It was from something in Mrs. Wix's tone, which in spite of caricature remained indescribable and  inimitable, that Maisie, before her term with her mother was over, drew this sense of a support, like a breast-high banister in a place of "drops," that would never give way.

confidence.word_example: She was taken into the  confidence of passions on which she fixed just the stare she might have had for images bounding across the wall in the slide of a magic-lantern.
confidence.word_definition: a secret that is confided or entrusted to another

objurgation.word_example: The  objurgation for instance launched in the carriage by her mother after she had at her father's bidding punctually performed was a missive that dropped into her memory with the dry rattle of a letter falling into a pillar-box.

deception.word_example: For Maisie moreover concealment had never necessarily seemed  deception; she had grown up among things as to which her foremost knowledge was that she was never to ask about them.

deliberate.word_example: The little girl  deliberated; even this consecrated tie had become as a cord she must suddenly snap.

quaver.word_example: The pathetic  quaver of this brave boast was not lost on Maisie, who threw herself so gratefully on the speaker's neck that, when they had concluded their embrace, the public tenderness of which, she felt, made up for the sacrifice she imposed, their companion had had time to lay a quick hand on Sir Claude and, with a glance at him or not, whisk him effectually out of sight.

lamentable.word_example: What was clear to any spectator was that the only link binding her to either parent was this  lamentable fact of her being a ready vessel for bitterness, a deep little porcelain cup in which biting acids could be mixed.

derision.word_example: She had learned that at these doors it was wise not to knock—this seemed to produce from within such sounds of  derision.

critical.word_example: It was of a horrid little  critical system, a tendency, in her silence, to judge her elders, that this lady suspected her, liking as she did, for her own part, a child to be simple and confiding.
critical.word_definition: marked by a tendency to find and call attention to flaws

suspicion.word_example: What at last, however, was in this connexion bewildering and a little frightening was the dawn of a  suspicion that a better way had been found to torment Mr. Farange than to deprive him of his periodical burden.
suspicion.word_definition: an impression that something might be the case

epitaph.word_example: "Poor little monkey!" she at last exclaimed; and the words were an  epitaph for the tomb of Maisie's childhood.
epitaph.word_definition: an inscription in memory of a buried person

fatalism.word_example: Maisie found in this exchange of asperities a fresh incitement to the unformulated  fatalism in which her sense of her own career had long since taken refuge; and it was the beginning for her of a deeper prevision that, in spite of Miss Overmore's brilliancy and Mrs. Wix's passion, she should live to see a change in the nature of the struggle she appeared to have come into the world to produce.
fatalism.word_definition: a mental attitude accepting that everything is predetermined

disproportionate.word_example: She was now old enough to understand how  disproportionate a stay she had already made with her father; and also old enough to enter a little into the ambiguity attending this excess, which oppressed her particularly whenever the question had been touched upon in talk with her governess.

acquire.word_example: Her pupil  acquired a vivid vision of every one who had ever, in her phrase, knocked against her—some of them oh so hard!—every one literally but Mr. Wix, her husband, as to whom nothing was mentioned save that he had been dead for ages.

impress.word_example: She was to remember always the words in which Moddle  impressed upon her that he did so give himself: "Your papa wishes you never to forget, you know, that he has been dreadfully put about."
impress.word_definition: have an emotional or cognitive impact upon

ignorance.word_example: Maisie's  ignorance of what she was to be saved from didn't diminish the pleasure of the thought that Miss Overmore was saving her.
ignorance.word_definition: the lack of knowledge or education

renunciation.word_example: Maisie knew Mrs. Farange had gone abroad, for she had had weeks and weeks before a letter from her beginning "My precious pet" and taking leave of her for an indeterminate time; but she had not seen in it a  renunciation of hatred or of the writer's policy of asserting herself, for the sharpest of all her impressions had been that there was nothing her mother would ever care so much about as to torment Mr. Farange.
renunciation.word_definition: rejecting or disowning or disclaiming as invalid

diversion.word_example: The dangers of the town equally with its  diversions added to Maisie's sense of being untutored and unclaimed.
diversion.word_definition: an activity that amuses or stimulates

prodigious.word_example: She puzzled out with imperfect signs, but with a  prodigious spirit, that she had been a centre of hatred and a messenger of insult, and that everything was bad because she had been employed to make it so.
prodigious.word_definition: great in size, force, extent, or degree

interminable.word_example: The litigation seemed  interminable and had in fact been complicated; but by the decision on the appeal the judgement of the divorce-court was confirmed as to the assignment of the child.

momentous.word_example: It was Miss Overmore, her first governess, who on a  momentous occasion had sown the seeds of secrecy; sown them not by anything she said, but by a mere roll of those fine eyes which Maisie already admired.

cunning.word_example: The only thing done, however, in general, took place when it was sighingly remarked that she fortunately wasn't all the year round where she happened to be at the awkward moment, and that, furthermore, either from extreme  cunning or from extreme stupidity, she appeared not to take things in.

defunct.word_example: The child was provided for, thanks to a crafty godmother, a  defunct aunt of Beale's, who had left her something in such a manner that the parents could appropriate only the income.
defunct.word_definition: having ceased to exist or live

omen.word_example: His account of the matter was most interesting, and Maisie, as if it were of bad  omen for her, stared at the picture in some dismay.
omen.word_definition: a sign of a thing about to happen

avidity.word_example: With the acuteness of her years, however, Maisie saw that her own  avidity would triumph, and she held out the picture to Miss Overmore as if she were quite proud of her mother.
avidity.word_definition: a positive feeling of wanting to push ahead with something

deficient.word_example: There was little indeed in the commerce of her companions that her precocious experience couldn't explain, for if they struck her as after all rather  deficient in that air of the honeymoon of which she had so often heard—in much detail, for instance, from Mrs. Wix—it was natural to judge the circumstance in the light of papa's proved disposition to contest the empire of the matrimonial tie.

perceptible.word_example: "It will be very interesting, my dear, you know, to find out what it is to-day that your father does mind. I'm sure I don't know!"—and she seemed to repeat, though with  perceptible resignation, her plaint of a moment before.
perceptible.word_definition: capable of being grasped by the mind or senses

reminiscence.word_example: The supreme hour was to furnish her with a vivid  reminiscence, that of a strange outbreak in the drawing-room on the part of Moddle, who, in reply to something her father had just said, cried aloud: "You ought to be perfectly ashamed of yourself—you ought to blush, sir, for the way you go on!"
reminiscence.word_definition: a mental impression retained and recalled from the past

precocious.word_example: Her embarrassment, of a  precocious instinctive order, attached itself to the idea that this was another of the matters it was not for her, as her mother used to say, to go into.

mirth.word_example: The child could see that at this Sir Claude, though still moved to  mirth, coloured a little; but he spoke to her very kindly.

devolve.word_example: She became aware in time that this phase wouldn't have shone by lessons, the care of her education being now only one of the many duties  devolving on Miss Overmore; a devolution as to which she was present at various passages between that lady and her father—passages significant, on either side, of dissent and even of displeasure.
devolve.word_definition: pass on or delegate to another

\"What Maisie Knew,\" Vocabulary from In.list_detailed_description: What can a young child know about the actions and desires of adults? Find out through the words of the omniscient narrator created by Henry James.

\"The Curious Incident of the Dog in the.list_brief_description: Multiply your vocabulary with these 3 lists of 43 words each. Then you'll know the logic of the narrator developed by Mark Haddon. Here are links to our lists f...

intuition.word_example: And this shows that  intuition can sometimes get things wrong. And  intuition is what people use in life to make decisions. But logic can help you work out the right answer.
intuition.word_definition: instinctive knowing, without the use of rational processes

digression.word_example: But this is what is called a  digression, and now I am going to go back to the fact that it was a Good Day.
digression.word_definition: a message that departs from the main subject

imagine.word_example: I also started with the dog because it happened to me and I find it hard to  imagine things which did not happen to me.
imagine.word_definition: form a mental image of something that is not present

logical.word_example: I think prime numbers are like life. They are very  logical but you could never work out the rules, even if you spent all your time thinking about them.
logical.word_definition: marked by an orderly and coherent relation of parts

evidence.word_example: And if she did that I might have more  evidence against him, or be able to Exclude Him from My Investigations.
evidence.word_definition: means by which an alleged matter is established or disproved

trespass.word_example: I reasoned that Father had only made me do a promise about five things, which were

caution.word_example: He replied, “No, a  caution means that we are going to keep a record of what you did, that you hit a policeman but that it was an accident and that you didn’t mean to hurt the policeman.”

uncomfortable.word_example: If I try to say the joke to myself, making the word mean the three different things at the same time, it is like hearing three different pieces of music at the same time, which is  uncomfortable and confusing and not nice like white noise.

measurement.word_example: Mother used to do this when she did the hoovering, so I made a special plan of where all the furniture was meant to be and did  measurements and I put everything back in its proper place afterward and then I felt better.
measurement.word_definition: assigning numbers to phenomena according to a rule

proper.word_example: This is another reason why I don’t like  proper novels, because they are lies about things which didn’t happen and they make me feel shaky and scared.
proper.word_definition: having all the qualities typical of the thing specified

faithful.word_example: Also, dogs are  faithful and they do not tell lies because they cannot talk.

observant.word_definition: quick to notice; showing quick and keen perception

surrounded.word_example: Also I wouldn’t be homesick at all because I’d be  surrounded by lots of the things I like, which are machines and computers and outer space.

approximately.word_example: It was nice in the police cell. It was almost a perfect cube, 2 meters long by 2 meters wide by 2 meters high. It contained  approximately 8 cubic meters of air.
approximately.word_definition: imprecise but fairly close to correct

investigation.word_example: And I explained that I couldn’t ask my father because the  investigation was a secret because he had told me to stay out of other people’s business.
investigation.word_definition: an inquiry into unfamiliar or questionable activities

suspect.word_example: If it was (c) I only knew one person who didn’t like Mrs. Shears, and that was Mr. Shears, who knew Wellington very well indeed. This meant that Mr. Shears was my Prime  Suspect.
suspect.word_definition: someone who is believed to be guilty of a crime

amnesia.word_example: I replied, “Somebody must know because the person who killed Wellington knows that they killed Wellington. Unless they were a mad person and didn’t know what they were doing. Or unless they had  amnesia.”
amnesia.word_definition: partial or total loss of memory

claustrophobia.word_example: You also have to be someone who would like being on their own in a tiny spacecraft thousands and thousands of miles away from the surface of the earth and not panic or get  claustrophobia or homesick or insane.
claustrophobia.word_definition: a morbid fear of being closed in a confined space

compartment.word_example: And sometimes Mrs. Shears stayed overnight at our house and I liked it when she did because she made things tidy and she arranged the jars and pans and tins in order of their height on the shelves in the kitchen and she always made their labels face outward and she put the knives and forks and spoons in the correct  compartments in the cutlery drawer.
compartment.word_definition: a partitioned section within a larger enclosed area

intelligent.word_example: To be a good astronaut you have to be  intelligent and I’m  intelligent.
intelligent.word_definition: having the capacity for thought and reason to a high degree

conclusion.word_example: Either that or it was a Red Herring, which is a clue which makes you come to a wrong  conclusion or something which looks like a clue but isn’t.
conclusion.word_definition: the proposition arrived at by logical reasoning

simile.word_example: This is not a metaphor, it is a  simile, which means that it really did look like there were two very small mice hiding in his nostrils, and if you make a picture in your head of a man with two very small mice hiding in his nostrils, you will know what the police inspector looked like.
simile.word_definition: a figure of speech expressing a resemblance between things

clever.word_example: Mr. Jeavons said that I was a very  clever boy. I said that I wasn’t  clever. I was just noticing how things were, and that wasn’t  clever.

risk.word_example: And if you are a detective you have to Take  Risks, and this was a Super Good Day, which meant it was a good day for Taking  Risks, so I said, “Do you know Mr. Shears?” which was like chatting.
risk.word_definition: a venture undertaken without regard to loss or injury

straightforward.word_example: He said I liked maths because it meant solving problems, and these problems were difficult and interesting but there was always a  straightforward answer at the end.

volume.word_example: It is like when you are upset and you hold the radio against your ear and you tune it halfway between two stations so that all you get is white noise and then you turn the  volume right up so that this is all you can hear and then you know you are safe because you cannot hear anything else.
volume.word_definition: the magnitude of sound, usually in a specified direction

difficulty.word_example: All the other children at my school are stupid. Except I’m not meant to call them stupid, even though this is what they are. I’m meant to say that they have learning  difficulties or that they have special needs. But this is stupid because everyone has learning  difficulties because learning to speak French or understanding relativity is difficult and also everyone has special needs
difficulty.word_definition: a factor causing trouble in achieving a positive result

psychologist.word_example: Mr. Jeavons, the  psychologist at the school, once asked me why 4 red cars in a row made it a Good Day, and 3 red cars in a row made it a Quite Good Day, and 5 red cars in a row made it a Super Good Day, and why 4 yellow cars in a row made it a Black Day, which is a day when I don’t speak to anyone and sit on my own reading books and don’t eat my lunch and Take No Risks.
psychologist.word_definition: a specialist in the science of mental life

concentrate.word_example: I like dogs. You always know what a dog is thinking. It has four moods. Happy, sad, cross and  concentrating.

complicated.word_example: Siobhan also says that if you close your mouth and breathe out loudly through your nose, it can mean that you are relaxed, or that you are bored, or that you are angry, and it all depends on how much air comes out of your nose and how fast and what shape your mouth is when you do it and how you are sitting and what you said just before and hundreds of other things which are too  complicated to work out in a few seconds.

particular.word_example: But there is only ever one thing which happened at a  particular time and a  particular place.
particular.word_definition: unique or specific to a person or thing or category

infinite.word_example: And there are an  infinite number of things which didn’t happen at that time and that place.

singularity.word_example: Except that there might be if you went through a black hole, but a black hole is what is called a  singularity, which means it is impossible to find out what is on the other side because the gravity of a black hole is so big that even electromagnetic waves like light can’t get out of it, and electromagnetic waves are how we get information about things which are far away.
singularity.word_definition: strangeness by virtue of being remarkable or unusual

exact.word_example: I was also wearing my watch and they wanted me to leave this at the desk as well but I said that I needed to keep my watch on because I needed to know exactly what time it was.
exact.word_definition: characterized by perfect conformity to fact or truth

inspiration.word_example: And as I was crossing the street I had a stroke of  inspiration about who might have killed Wellington.
inspiration.word_definition: a sudden intuition as part of solving a problem

prime.word_example: Chapters in books are usually given the cardinal numbers 1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6 and so on. But I have decided to give my chapters  prime numbers 2, 3, 5, 7, 11, 13 and so on because I like  prime numbers.
prime.word_definition: a number that has no factor but itself and 1

pressure.word_example: So I asked her the same question again, because in a murder mystery novel when someone doesn’t want to answer a question it is because they are trying to keep a secret or trying to stop someone from getting into trouble, which means that the answers to those questions are the most important answers of all, and that is why the detective has to put that person under  pressure.
pressure.word_definition: an oppressive condition of physical or mental distress

suspicious.word_example: I said, “Did you see anything  suspicious on Thursday evening?”

value.word_example: Or if you see someone’s name and you give each letter a  value from 1 to 26 (a = 1, b = 2, etc.) and you add the numbers up in your head and you find that it makes a prime number, like Jesus Christ (151), or Scooby-Doo (113), or Sherlock Holmes (163), or Doctor Watson (167).
value.word_definition: a numerical quantity measured or assigned or computed

slander.word_example: I wondered whether Mrs. Shears had told the police that I had killed Wellington and whether, when the police found out that she had lied, she would go to prison. Because telling lies about people is called  slander.
slander.word_definition: words falsely spoken that damage the reputation of another

apocryphal.word_example: But he wasn’t called anything because this is an  apocryphal story, which means that it is a lie, too.

physics.word_example: I’m not a spazzer, which means spastic, not like Francis, who is a spazzer, and even though I probably won’t become an astronaut, I am going to go to university and study mathematics, or  physics, or  physics and mathematics (which is a Joint Honor School), because I like mathematics and  physics and I’m very good at them.
physics.word_definition: the science of matter and energy and their interactions

precedent.word_example: Mrs. Gascoyne said they didn’t want to treat me differently from everyone else in the school because then everyone would want to be treated differently and it would set a  precedent.
precedent.word_definition: an example that is used to justify similar occurrences

\"The Curious Incident of the Dog in the.list_detailed_description: Multiply your vocabulary with these 3 lists of 43 words each. Then you'll know the logic of the narrator developed by Mark Haddon.

\"Purple Hibiscus,\" Vocabulary from Pal.list_brief_description: Chimamanda Ngozi Adichie describes lives falling apart from religious, political, and familial conflicts in Nigeria. Here are links to our lists for the novel: ...

coup.word_example: Coups begat  coups, he said, telling us about the bloody  coups of the sixties, which ended up in civil war just after he left Nigeria to study in England.
coup.word_definition: a sudden and decisive change of government by force

modesty.word_example: And I would sit with my knees pressed together, next to Jaja, trying hard to keep my face blank, to keep the pride from showing, because Papa said  modesty was very important.

desolate.word_example: Jaja said that when he looked through the keyhole, Papa was holding Yewande’s hand and praying, telling her to repeat “none of those who trust in Him shall be left  desolate.”

thwart.word_example: He prayed for the food first, then he asked God to forgive those who had tried to  thwart His will, who had put selfish desires first and had not wanted to visit His servant after Mass.
thwart.word_definition: hinder or prevent, as an effort, plan, or desire

limp.word_example: She  limped slightly, as though one leg were shorter than the other, a gait that made her seem even smaller than she was.
limp.word_definition: walk impeded by some physical injury

confession.word_example: “I just like running,” I said, and wondered if I would count that as a lie when I made  confession next Saturday, if I would add it to the lie about not having heard Mother Lucy the first time.
confession.word_definition: the act of a penitent disclosing sinfulness before a priest

martial.word_example: Papa had just checkmated Jaja when we heard the  martial music on the radio, the solemn strains making us stop to listen.

demonstrator.word_example: Our branches never looked as bright as the  demonstrators’, though, and sometimes as we drove past, I wondered what it would be like to join them, chanting “Freedom,” standing in the way of cars.
demonstrator.word_definition: someone participating in a public display of group feeling

jagged.word_example: Jaja knelt beside Mama, flattened the church bulletin he held into a dustpan, and placed a  jagged ceramic piece on it.
jagged.word_definition: having a sharply uneven surface or outline

vulnerable.word_example: His eyes were swollen and red, and somehow that made him look younger, more  vulnerable.
vulnerable.word_definition: capable of being wounded or hurt

native.word_example: But he allowed offertory songs in Igbo; he called them  native songs, and when he said “ native” his straight-line lips turned down at the corners to form an inverted U.
native.word_definition: relating to people inhabiting a region from the beginning

baron.word_example: I knew his arrest was because of the big cover story in the last Standard, a story about how the Head of State and his wife had paid people to transport heroin abroad, a story that questioned the recent execution of three men and who the real drug  barons were.
baron.word_definition: a very wealthy or powerful businessman

indulgent.word_example: Mama shook her head and smiled, the  indulgent smile that stretched across her face when she talked about people who believed in oracles, or when relatives suggested she consult a witch doctor, or when people recounted tales of digging up hair tufts and animal bones wrapped in cloth that had been buried in their front yards to ward off progress.

parish.word_example: Father Benedict had changed things in the  parish, such as insisting that the Credo and kyrie be recited only in Latin; Igbo was not acceptable.

intone.word_example: Afterward, he  intoned the Blessed Virgin in several different titles while we responded, “Pray for us.”
intone.word_definition: recite musically; recite as a chant or a psalm

figurine.word_example: Maybe Mama had realized that she would not need the  figurines anymore; that when Papa threw the missal at Jaja, it was not just the  figurines that came tumbling down, it was everything.
figurine.word_definition: a small carved or molded figure

communion.word_example: Things started to fall apart at home when my brother, Jaja, did not go to  communion and Papa flung his heavy missal across the room and broke the figurines on the etagere.
communion.word_definition: a group of Christians with a common religious faith

mysterious.word_example: “They do not know that God works in  mysterious ways.”

swell.word_example: The last time, only two weeks ago, when her  swollen eye was still the black-purple color of an overripe avocado, she had rearranged them after she polished them.

compliment.word_example: He was supposed to say something now, to contribute, to  compliment Papa’s new product.

urge.word_example: That night, when Papa prayed, he added longer passages  urging God to bring about the downfall of the Godless men ruling our country, and he intoned over and over, “Our Lady Shield of the Nigerian People, pray for us.”

fragment.word_example: Her eyes were vacant, like the eyes of those mad people who wandered around the roadside garbage dumps in town, pulling grimy, torn canvas bags with their life  fragments inside.
fragment.word_definition: a piece broken off or cut off of something else

secular.word_example: “Wafer” was too  secular, wafer was what one of Papa’s factories made—chocolate wafer, banana wafer, what people bought their children to give them a treat better than biscuits.
secular.word_definition: characteristic of this world rather than the spiritual world

mortal.word_example: He always encouraged Father Benedict to call and win that person back into the fold; nothing but  mortal sin would keep a person away from communion two Sundays in a row.
mortal.word_definition: involving loss of divine grace or spiritual death

deliver.word_example: “God will  deliver us,” I said, knowing Papa would like my saying that.

defiance.word_example: Jaja’s  defiance seemed to me now like Aunty Ifeoma’s experimental purple hibiscus: rare, fragrant with the undertones of freedom, a different kind of freedom from the one the crowds waving green leaves chanted at Government Square after the coup.
defiance.word_definition: an act boldly resisting authority or an opposing force

turbulence.word_example: He lumbered upstairs, each heavy step creating  turbulence in my head, and went into Jaja’s room.
turbulence.word_definition: a state of violent disturbance and disorder

execution.word_example: I told Jaja what a girl in my class had said: that her mother turned their TV off, asking why she should watch fellow human beings die, asking what was wrong with all those people who had gathered at the  execution ground.
execution.word_definition: putting a condemned person to death

stale.word_example: Some of the holy water landed on my lips, and I tasted the  stale saltiness of it as we prayed.
stale.word_definition: lacking freshness, palatability, or showing deterioration

missionary.word_example: I had heard this all before, how hard he had worked, how much the  missionary Reverend Sisters and priests had taught him, things he would never have learned from his idol-worshiping father, my Papa-Nnukwu.
missionary.word_definition: someone who attempts to convert others to a doctrine

faithful.word_example: Finally, stuttering, I said, “I pledge to Nigeria, my country/To be  faithful, loyal, and honest...”

demolish.word_example: When we got into the car, Kevin told Mama that the soldiers had been ordered to  demolish the vegetable stalls because they were illegal structures.

meticulously.word_example: Papa liked order. It showed even in the schedules themselves, the way his  meticulously drawn lines, in black ink, cut across each day, separating study from siesta, siesta from family time, family time from eating, eating from prayer, prayer from sleep.
meticulously.word_definition: in a manner marked by extreme care of details

acknowledge.word_example: I wanted to say I came second so that he would know immediately, so that I would  acknowledge my failure, but instead I said, “Yes,” and handed him the report card.
acknowledge.word_definition: declare to be true or admit the existence or reality of

solemnity.word_example: Also, hand clapping was to be kept at a minimum, lest the  solemnity of Mass be compromised.

steady.word_example: It was like balancing a sack of gravel on my head every day at school and not being allowed to  steady it with my hand.

triumphant.word_example: Brother Eugene spoke out for freedom. How many of us have stood up for the truth? How many of us have reflected the  Triumphant Entry?
triumphant.word_definition: joyful and proud especially because of success

colonial.word_example: Papa’s sister, Aunty Ifeoma, said once that Papa was too much of a  colonial product.
colonial.word_definition: a resident of an area controlled by a distant country

benediction.word_example: Our steps on the stairs were as measured and as silent as our Sundays: the silence of waiting until Papa was done with his siesta so we could have lunch; the silence of reflection time, when Papa gave us a scripture passage or a book by one of the early church fathers to read and meditate on; the silence of evening rosary; the silence of driving to the church for  benediction afterward.
benediction.word_definition: a ceremonial prayer invoking divine protection

corrupt.word_example: Of course, Papa told us, the politicians were  corrupt, and the Standard had written many stories about the cabinet ministers who stashed money in foreign bank accounts, money meant for paying teachers’ salaries and building roads.
corrupt.word_definition: not straight; dishonest or immoral or evasive

\"Purple Hibiscus,\" Vocabulary from Pal.list_detailed_description: Chimamanda Ngozi Adichie describes lives falling apart from religious, political, and familial conflicts in Nigeria.

\"Nothing But the Truth,\" Vocabulary fr.list_brief_description: Using journal entries, memos, letters, and dialogue, award-winning author Avi pokes fun at high school, politics, and the media. This satirical novel demonstrat...

portrayal.word_example: Can people learn from this  portrayal of a dog? Expand on these ideas.
portrayal.word_definition: a word picture of a person's appearance and character

capacity.word_example: And I like them and their  capacity for independence.

respectful.word_example: Say, “Please all rise and stand at  respectful, silent attention for the playing of our national anthem.”
respectful.word_definition: exhibiting an attitude of admiration or esteem

steadfast.word_example: All the same, I remain  steadfast in my belief that my life was meant to be the bringing of fine literature to young minds.
steadfast.word_definition: marked by firm determination or resolution; not shakable

acknowledge.word_example: The Call of the Wild is an  acknowledged masterpiece of American literature. You are not required to like it.
acknowledge.word_definition: express recognition of the presence or existence of

significance.word_example: Question four: What is the  significance of Jack London's choice in making Buck, the dog in The Call of the Wild, the focus of his novel?
significance.word_definition: the message that is intended or expressed

symbolic.word_example: Is the dog meant to be  symbolic? Explain your answer.
symbolic.word_definition: serving as a visible sign for something abstract

resistance.word_example: No, it’s a certain something—a  resistance—to accepting the idea that literature is important.
resistance.word_definition: the action of opposing something that you disagree with

strategy.word_example: You have to have a  strategy—know when to take it easy, know when to turn on the juice.
strategy.word_definition: an elaborate and systematic plan of action

congregation.word_example: She used to be in the West Fork Church  congregation years ago.
congregation.word_definition: a group of people who habitually attend a given church

wit.word_example: MR. LUNSER: Ah, the famous  wit and wisdom of Mr. Malloy. Philip, I'm the only one allowed to make jokes around here.
wit.word_definition: verbal skill that has the power to evoke laughter

gleaming.word_example: Oh, say, can you see, by the dawn's early light,

ambition.word_example: Worst of all, like so many of them, he exhibits no desire to learn. No  ambition at all!

reluctantly.word_example: They come to literature  reluctantly at best, fighting me every inch of the way.
reluctantly.word_definition: with a certain degree of unwillingness

stead.word_example: The Principal, or in his stead the Assistant Principal, or in his stead a designated member of the faculty, will say, “Good morning to all students, faculty, and staff. Today is Monday (or whatever day), January (or whatever month) 3 (or whatever day).
stead.word_definition: the place properly occupied or served by another

gallantly.word_example: O'er the ramparts we watched were so  gallantly streaming?
gallantly.word_definition: in a heroic or brave manner

perilous.word_example: Whose broad stripes and bright stars, through the  perilous fight.

mock.word_example: Now if I were to laugh or  mock, he would be insulted.

strive.word_example: But this Philip—an only son, by the way, which may be the problem—is only a middling student, and it’s a shame. A nice-looking boy. A boy I like. Intelligent. With real potential. Perhaps that’s why he irritates me so—for he shows no desire to  strive, to make sacrifices for the betterment of self, the way we were taught.
strive.word_definition: to exert much effort or energy

\"Nothing But the Truth,\" Vocabulary fr.list_detailed_description: Using journal entries, memos, letters, and dialogue, award-winning author Avi pokes fun at high school, politics, and the media. This satirical novel demonstrates that truth is always subjective.

\"Maniac Magee,\" Vocabulary from Before.list_brief_description: Award-winning author Jerry Spinelli used these words to describe the issues surrounding a homeless orphan in a racially divided town. Here are links to our list...

claim.word_example: If you listen to everybody who  claims to have seen Jeffrey-Maniac Magee that first day, there must have been ten thousand people and a parade of fire trucks waiting for him at the town limits.

stupefied.word_example: As the  stupefied high-schoolers were leaving the scene, they looked back.
stupefied.word_definition: as if struck dumb with astonishment and surprise

bellow.word_example: Then the giggling stopped, and eyes started to shift and heads started to turn, because now everybody could see that this wasn’t part of the show at all, that little Jeffrey Magee wasn’t supposed to be up there on the risers, pointing to his aunt and uncle,  bellowing out from the midst of the chorus: “Talk! Talk, will ya! Talk! Talk! Talk!”

glare.word_example: And when Mars Bar stepped off a curb and combined the  glare with his super-slow dip-stride slumpshuffle, well, it was said he could back up traffic all the way to Bridgeport while he took ten minutes to cross the street.

stunned.word_example: It sailed back over the up-looking gym-classers, spiraling more perfectly than anything Brian Denehy had ever thrown, and landed in the outstretched hands of still  stunned Hands Down.
stunned.word_definition: filled with the emotional impact of overwhelming surprise

forbidden.word_example: They saw the kid, cool times ten, stretch out on the  forbidden steps and open his book to read.

befuddled.word_example: Maniac was  befuddled. “I don’t know. One minute you’re yelling at me, the next minute you’re giving me a bite of your candy bar.”
befuddled.word_definition: perplexed by many conflicting situations or statements

converge.word_example: He loved the Fourth of July block party, when the whole East End  converged for a day and night of games and music and grilled chicken and ribs and sweet-potato pie and dancing until the last firecracker, and then some.
converge.word_definition: move or draw together at a certain location

rant.word_example: And the man was croaking,  ranting, not to Maniac now but to the people. “What happens when we go over there? Black is black! White is white! The sheep lie not with the lion! The sheep knows his own! His own kind!”
rant.word_definition: talk at length in a noisy, excited, or angry manner

glum.word_example: This was driving Amanda bonkers. He was acting so different, all  glum, and wiseacre answers.

victim.word_example: In less than five minutes, while Mrs. Beale and Amanda cleaned up the floor, Hester and Lester and their dog Bow Wow were in the backyard wrestling and tickling and jumping and just generally going wild with their new buddy — and  victim — Maniac Magee.
victim.word_definition: an unfortunate person who suffers from adverse circumstances

quiver.word_example: Maniac’s lip started to  quiver, and right there, with the car idling in the middle of the street, Maniac told him that he didn’t really have a home, unless you counted the deer shed at the zoo.

apparently.word_example: Mr. Beale knew what his passenger  apparently didn’t: East End was East End and West End was West End, and the house this white lad was pointing to was filled with black people, just like every other house on up to Hector Street.

propel.word_example: He learned how to jump in front of the gusher and let it  propel him halfway across the street.
propel.word_definition: cause to move forward with force

pelt.word_example: yells behind him now, war whoops, stones  pelting the water, stinging his back ...
pelt.word_definition: attack and bombard with or as if with missiles

fascinated.word_example: Ordinarily, he would have returned it immediately, but he was so  fascinated by the story of the Children’s Crusade that he kept it and read it the next day.
fascinated.word_definition: having your attention fixated as though by a spell

commotion.word_example: Later on that first day, there was a  commotion in the West End.

lurch.word_example: But now the frog shot through his legs, over to the mound, and now toward shortstop and now toward second, and McNab was  lurching and lunging, throwing his hat at the frog, throwing his glove, and everybody was screaming, and the kid was rounding third and digging for home, and — unbe-froggable! — the “ball” was heading back home too!

feat.word_example: The kid was trying for an inside-the-park home-run bunt — the rarest  feat in baseball, something that had hardly ever been done with a ball, and never with a frog — and to be the pitcher who let such a thing happen — well, McNab could already feel his strikeout record fading to a mere grain in the sandlot of history.

convention.word_example: The Cobras were laughing because they figured the dumb, scraggly runt would get out of the East End in about as good shape as a bare big toe in a  convention of snapping turtles.

survive.word_example: If anybody could  survive on the loose, it would be this kid who showed up from Hollidaysburg. Who slept on floors. Who outran dogs.
survive.word_definition: continue to live through hardship or adversity

relief.word_example: He looked himself over pretty hard and came up with at least seven different shades and colors right on his own skin, not one of them being what he would call white (except for his eyeballs, which weren’t any whiter than the eyeballs of the kids in the East End).
relief.word_definition: the condition of being comfortable or alleviated of distress

intend.word_example: And some say he only  intended to pause here but that he stayed because he was so happy to make a friend.
intend.word_definition: have in mind as a purpose

carcass.word_example: The phantom Samaritan stuck the book between his teeth, crouched down, hoisted Arnold Jones’s limp  carcass over his shoulder, and hauled him out of there like a sack of flour.
carcass.word_definition: the dead body of an animal

sacrifice.word_example: So, there’s Arnold Jones, held up by all these hands, flopping and kicking and shrieking like some poor Aztec human  sacrifice about to be tossed off a pyramid.
sacrifice.word_definition: the act of killing in order to appease a deity

lunge.word_example: Three springy steps down from the risers — girls in pastel dresses screaming, the music director  lunging — a leap from the stage, out the side door and into the starry, sweet, onion-grass-smelling night.

snarl.word_example: But nobody stepped off a curb, everybody kept moving north, an ugly,  snarling black-and-white escort for the kid in the middle.
snarl.word_definition: make an angry, sharp, or abrupt noise

intercept.word_example: Buzzing about the new kid in town. The stranger kid. Scraggly. Carrying a book. Flap-soled sneakers.

hurl.word_example: She tore a book from the suitcase,  hurled it at him — “Here!” — and dashed into school.

contortion.word_example: It was made of string, but it had more  contortions, ins and outs, twists and turns and dips and doodles than the brain of Albert Einstein himself.
contortion.word_definition: a tortuous and twisted shape or position

legend.word_example: But that’s okay, because the history of a kid is one part fact, two parts  legend, and three parts snowball.
legend.word_definition: a story about mythical or supernatural beings or events

drench.word_example: He  drenched himself in all the wet and warm and happy.
drench.word_definition: cover with liquid; pour liquid onto

maniac.word_example: Of course, to be accurate, he wasn’t really  Maniac then. He was Jeffrey. Jeffrey Lionel Magee.

pandemonium.word_definition: a state of extreme confusion and disorder

hinge.word_example: A couple of people truly remember, and here’s what they saw: a scraggly little kid jogging toward them, the soles of both sneakers hanging by their  hinges and flopping open like dog tongues each time they came up from the pavement.
hinge.word_definition: a joint that holds two parts together so that one can swing

legacy.word_example: And sometimes the girl holding one end of the rope is from the West side of Hector, and the girl on the other end is from the East side; and if you’re looking for Maniac Magee’s  legacy, or monument, that’s as good as any — even if it wasn’t really a bull.
legacy.word_definition: a gift of personal property by will

scowl.word_example: Suddenly his world was very small and very simple: a brick wall behind him, a row of  scowling faces in front of him.

spectator.word_example: The rest of the  spectators watched Maniac poke and tug and pick at the knot.
spectator.word_definition: a close observer; someone who looks at something

hallucination.word_example: Another swears it was a mirage, some sort of  hallucination, possibly caused by evil emanations surrounding 803 Oriole Street.

opponent.word_example: Others say his mouth was more grim than grin, that his eyes lit up like flashbulbs, because he knew he was finally facing a knot that would stand up and fight, a worthy  opponent.

\"Maniac Magee,\" Vocabulary from Before.list_detailed_description: Award-winning author Jerry Spinelli used these words to describe the issues surrounding a homeless orphan in a racially divided town.

\"Ivanhoe,\" Vocabulary from Chapters 1-.list_brief_description: Images of medieval England were popularized by Walter Scott through his portrayal of knights, kings, and outlaws. Here are links to our lists for the novel: Cha...

ennui.word_example: The ladies, in particular, were not disposed to scan too nicely the morals of a man who was a professed admirer of their sex, and who possessed many means of dispelling the  ennui which was too apt to intrude upon the halls and bowers of an ancient feudal castle.
ennui.word_definition: the feeling of being bored by something tedious

largesse.word_example: The heralds finished their proclamation with their usual cry of “ Largesse,  largesse, gallant knights!” and gold and silver pieces were showered on them from the galleries, it being a high point of chivalry to exhibit liberality towards those whom the age accounted at once the secretaries and the historians of honour.
largesse.word_definition: a gift or money given, usually ostentatiously

guerdon.word_example: “That will I do blithely,” replied the Pilgrim, “and without  guerdon; my oath, for a time, prohibits me from touching gold.”

ignoble.word_example: In the anteroom he found his attendant Anwold, who, taking the torch from the hand of the waiting-maid, conducted him with more haste than ceremony to an exterior and  ignoble part of the building, where a number of small apartments, or rather cells, served for sleeping places to the lower order of domestics, and to strangers of mean degree.
ignoble.word_definition: completely lacking nobility in character or purpose

exorbitant.word_example: The nobles, whose power had become  exorbitant during the reign of Stephen, and whom the prudence of Henry the Second had scarce reduced to some degree of subjection to the crown, had now resumed their ancient license in its utmost extent
exorbitant.word_definition: greatly exceeding bounds of reason or moderation

extirpate.word_example: The whole race of Saxon princes and nobles had been  extirpated or disinherited, with few or no exceptions; nor were the numbers great who possessed land in the country of their fathers, even as proprietors of the second, or of yet inferior classes.
extirpate.word_definition: destroy completely, as if down to the roots

canvass.word_example: It contained the Norman word “melee”, (to express the general conflict,) and it evinced some indifference to the honour of the country; but it was spoken by Athelstane, whom he held in such profound respect, that he would not trust himself to  canvass his motives or his foibles.
canvass.word_definition: consider in detail in order to discover essential features

obsequious.word_example: “The wiser man thou,” said John, with a peal of laughter, in which his gay followers obsequiously joined.
obsequious.word_definition: attempting to win favor from influential people by flattery

dais.word_example: For about one quarter of the length of the apartment, the floor was raised by a step, and this space, which was called the  dais, was occupied only by the principal members of the family, and visitors of distinction.
dais.word_definition: a platform raised above the surrounding level

seditious.word_example: “Prior Aymer,” said the Templar, “you are a man of gallantry, learned in the study of beauty, and as expert as a troubadour in all matters concerning the ‘arrets’ of love; but I shall expect much beauty in this celebrated Rowena to counterbalance the self-denial and forbearance which I must exert if I am to court the favor of such a  seditious churl as you have described her father Cedric.”

libertine.word_example: Such an expression is often mistaken for manly frankness, when in truth it arises from the reckless indifference of a  libertine disposition, conscious of superiority of birth, of wealth, or of some other adventitious advantage, totally unconnected with personal merit.

ecclesiastical.word_example: Besides the massive golden signet ring, which marked his  ecclesiastical dignity, his fingers, though contrary to the canon, were loaded with precious gems; his sandals were of the finest leather which was imported from Spain; his beard trimmed to as small dimensions as his order would possibly permit, and his shaven crown concealed by a scarlet cap richly embroidered.
ecclesiastical.word_definition: of or associated with a church

retinue.word_example: The whole appearance of this warrior and his  retinue was wild and outlandish; the dress of his squires was gorgeous, and his Eastern attendants wore silver collars round their throats, and bracelets of the same metal upon their swarthy arms and legs, of which the former were naked from the elbow, and the latter from mid-leg to ankle.
retinue.word_definition: the group following and attending to some important person

sinew.word_example: “Oh, holy Moses! O, blessed Aaron! the dream is not dreamed for nought, and the vision cometh not in vain! I feel their irons already tear my  sinews! I feel the rack pass over my body like the saws, and harrows, and axes of iron over the men of Rabbah, and of the cities of the children of Ammon!”
sinew.word_definition: a band of tissue connecting a muscle to its bony attachment

unwonted.word_example: “Knowest thou,” said the Jester, “my good friend Gurth, that thou art strangely courteous and most unwontedly pious on this summer morning? I would I were a black Prior or a barefoot Palmer, to avail myself of thy  unwonted zeal and courtesy--certes, I would make more out of it than a kiss of the hand.”

privilege.word_example: Gurth, knowing his master’s irritable temper, attempted no exculpation; but the Jester, who could presume upon Cedric’s tolerance, by virtue of his  privileges as a fool, replied for them both; “In troth, uncle Cedric, you are neither wise nor reasonable tonight.”
privilege.word_definition: a special advantage or benefit not enjoyed by all

choleric.word_example: It appeared, indeed, from the countenance of this proprietor, that he was of a frank, but hasty and  choleric temper.

quaff.word_example: Without alighting from his horse, the conqueror called for a bowl of wine, and opening the beaver, or lower part of his helmet, announced that he  quaffed it, “To all true English hearts, and to the confusion of foreign tyrants.”
quaff.word_definition: to swallow hurriedly or greedily or in one draught

venerable.word_example: “In truth,  venerable father,” answered the Jester, “the Saracen head of your right reverend companion has frightened out of mine the way home--I am not sure I shall get there tonight myself.”

oppression.word_example: Such being our chief scene, the date of our story refers to a period towards the end of the reign of Richard I, when his return from his long captivity had become an event rather wished than hoped for by his despairing subjects, who were in the meantime subjected to every species of subordinate  oppression.
oppression.word_definition: the state of being kept down by unjust use of authority

treason.word_example: For the love of God, young man, betray me not—for the sake of the Great Father who made us all, Jew as well as Gentile, Israelite and Ishmaelite—do me no  treason!

betoken.word_example: Having dispelled the cold, he turned eagerly to the smoking mess which was placed before him, and ate with a haste and an apparent relish, that seemed to  betoken long abstinence from food.
betoken.word_definition: be a signal for or a symptom of

courtesy.word_example: Yet, brother, take my advice, and file your tongue to a little more  courtesy than your habits of predominating over infidel captives and Eastern bondsmen have accustomed you.

obligation.word_example: Without disputing a maxim urged by such grave authority, the Palmer thanked them for their courtesy, but observed that he had included in his religious vow, an  obligation never to speak in the kitchen on matters which were prohibited in the hall.
obligation.word_definition: the state of being bound to do or pay something

flourish.word_example: Here haunted of yore the fabulous Dragon of Wantley; here were fought many of the most desperate battles during the Civil Wars of the Roses; and here also  flourished in ancient times those bands of gallant outlaws, whose deeds have been rendered so popular in English song.

harangue.word_example: When the Prior had ceased what he meant as a conciliatory  harangue, his companion said briefly and emphatically, “I speak ever French, the language of King Richard and his nobles; but I understand English sufficiently to communicate with the natives of the country.”
harangue.word_definition: a loud bombastic declamation expressed with strong emotion

extort.word_example: It is a well-known story of King John, that he confined a wealthy Jew in one of the royal castles, and daily caused one of his teeth to be torn out, until, when the jaw of the unhappy Israelite was half disfurnished, he consented to pay a large sum, which it was the tyrant’s object to  extort from him.

hostile.word_example: Four generations had not sufficed to blend the  hostile blood of the Normans and Anglo-Saxons, or to unite, by common language and mutual interests, two  hostile races, one of which still felt the elation of triumph, while the other groaned under all the consequences of defeat.
hostile.word_definition: characterized by enmity or ill will

bulwark.word_example: “The fool,” answered Wamba, raising the relics of a gammon of bacon, “will take care to erect a  bulwark against the knave.”
bulwark.word_definition: an embankment built around a space for defensive purposes

imperious.word_example: It was to this person, such as we have described him, that the Prince addressed his  imperious command to make place for Isaac and Rebecca.

benison.word_example: “Good-night, and Our Lady’s  benison,” said the Palmer, with composure; and his guide moved forward.

chastise.word_example: “What mean these fellows by their capricious insolence?” said the Templar to the Benedictine, “and why did you prevent me from  chastising it?”

palisade.word_example: It was strongly secured by a  palisade on each side, as was the esplanade in front of the pavilions, and the whole was guarded by men-at-arms.
palisade.word_definition: a strong fence made of stakes driven into the ground

doff.word_example: He wore a high square yellow cap of a peculiar fashion, assigned to his nation to distinguish them from Christians, and which he  doffed with great humility at the door of the hall.

serf.word_example: That of the  serf, or bondsman, was sad and sullen; his aspect was bent on the ground with an appearance of deep dejection, which might be almost construed into apathy, had not the fire which occasionally sparkled in his red eye manifested that there slumbered, under the appearance of sullen despondency, a sense of oppression, and a disposition to resistance.
serf.word_definition: a person bound to the land and owned by the feudal lord

mercenary.word_example: “The Saxon porker,” he said, “is either asleep or minds me not—Prick him with your lance, De Bracy,” speaking to a knight who rode near him, the leader of a band of Free Companions, or Condottieri; that is, of  mercenaries belonging to no particular nation, but attached for the time to any prince by whom they were paid.
mercenary.word_definition: a person hired to fight for another country than their own

alms.word_example: “Accept this  alms, friend,” continued the lady, offering a piece of gold, “in acknowledgment of thy painful travail, and of the shrines thou hast visited.”
alms.word_definition: money or goods contributed to the poor

consequence.word_example: Gurth, whose occupation, though now held so mean, gave him as much  consequence in Saxon England as that of Eumaeus in Ithaca, was offended at the familiar and commanding tone assumed by the Palmer.

supplicate.word_example: On the contrary, as he passed along the file, casting a timid  supplicating glance, and turning towards each of those who occupied the lower end of the board, the Saxon domestics squared their shoulders, and continued to devour their supper with great perseverance, paying not the least attention to the wants of the new guest.

wrought.word_example: This upper robe concealed what at first view seemed rather inconsistent with its form, a shirt, namely, of linked mail, with sleeves and gloves of the same, curiously plaited and interwoven, as flexible to the body as those which are now  wrought in the stocking-loom, out of less obdurate materials.
wrought.word_definition: shaped to fit by altering the contours of a pliable mass

\"Ivanhoe,\" Vocabulary from Chapters 1-.list_detailed_description: Images of medieval England were popularized by Walter Scott through his portrayal of knights, kings, and outlaws.

\"Monster,\" Vocabulary from Pages 1-172.list_brief_description: "Monster" tackles justice, mystery, and a teenager's personal experience. Learn these words from award-winning author Walter Dean Myers's book. Here are our lis...

traverse.word_example: The bullet entered the body on the left side and  traversed upward through the left lung.

diminutive.word_example: The  diminutive 58-year-old retired school librarian is neatly dressed.

cacophony.word_example: As camera zooms in, we pick up a  cacophony of sounds.
cacophony.word_definition: a loud harsh or strident noise

respective.word_example: They return to their  respective tables and the judge nods to the court stenographer, who straightens up, ready to take down the day's proceedings.

grandiose.word_example: Miss Petrocelli, representing the State, has presented this case in very broad and  grandiose terms.
grandiose.word_definition: impressive because of unnecessary largeness or magnificence

culprit.word_example: She sits down, obviously pleased that the  culprits have been caught.
culprit.word_definition: someone or something responsible for harm or wrongdoing

acknowledge.word_definition: express recognition of the presence or existence of

objection.word_example: Objection! Defense counsel is stepping over his bounds.
objection.word_definition: the act of expressing earnest opposition or protest

perpetrator.word_example: It's my understanding that the crime-scene technicians didn't find any fingerprints they could establish as belonging to a  perpetrator.

grotesque.word_example: Black-and-white shots from various angles of body in  grotesque position.
grotesque.word_definition: distorted and unnatural in shape or size

testify.word_example: You  testified in a pretrial hearing that you had some trouble  testifying that Mr. King was involved in the event, is that correct?
testify.word_definition: give a solemn statement in a court of law

prejudice.word_example: With him in prison gear, that  prejudices my client.

appeal.word_example: The talk is lawyer talk, with all the older guys talking about  appeals and "mistakes" that the judge made.
appeal.word_definition: a legal proceeding to review of a lower court decision

defendant.word_example: The 2  defendants you see before you will be shown to be participants in that act and are being charged with felony murder.
defendant.word_definition: someone against whom an action is brought in a court of law

wrench.word_example: The smile that came to her lips was one she  wrenched from someplace deep inside of her.
wrench.word_definition: twist or pull violently or suddenly

dispensary.word_example: When the gloves came, the guards put them on, handcuffed the guy, and then took him to the  dispensary.
dispensary.word_definition: clinic where medicine and medical supplies are distributed

felony.word_definition: a serious crime, such as murder or arson

impede.word_example: Another of the planners of this crime was to stand outside the drugstore and  impede anyone chasing the robbers.
impede.word_definition: be a hindrance or obstacle to

conspirator.word_example: Two of the  conspirators will testify to their understanding of this fact.
conspirator.word_definition: a member of a plot to carry out some harmful or illegal act

admissible.word_example: I'm ruling the kid's testimony is  admissible.

verdict.word_example: But in the end you will have the opportunity to judge the State's key witnesses and to deliver a just  verdict.
verdict.word_definition: findings of a jury on issues submitted to it for decision

prosecutor.word_example: I'll call it what the lady who is the  prosecutor called me.
prosecutor.word_definition: an official conducting criminal cases on behalf of the state

testimony.word_example: I'm ruling the kid's  testimony is admissible.
testimony.word_definition: a solemn statement made under oath

parole.word_example: Chances are the judge will push for life without  parole.
