\"Dracula,\" Vocabulary from Chapters 1-.list_brief_description: Enter the world of the UnDead through these words from eyewitness accounts presented by Bram Stoker. This list focuses on Dracula. Here are links to our lists f...

obstruct.word_example: Once there appeared a strange optical effect: when he stood between me and the flame he did not  obstruct it, for I could see its ghostly flicker all the same.

profusion.word_example: His eyebrows were very massive, almost meeting over the nose, and with bushy hair that seemed to curl in its own  profusion.
profusion.word_definition: the property of being extremely abundant

inspire.word_example: Was it not this Dracula, indeed, who  inspired that other of his race who in a later age again and again brought his forces over the great river into Turkey-land; who, when he was beaten back, came again, and again, and again, though he had to come alone from the bloody field where his troops were being slaughtered, since he knew that he alone could ultimately triumph!
inspire.word_definition: serve as the inciting cause of

bearing.word_example: while Count Dracula was speaking, there was that in his eyes and in his  bearing which made me remember that I was a prisoner, and that if I wished it I could have no choice.
bearing.word_definition: characteristic way of holding one's body

malice.word_example: The last glimpse I had was of the bloated face, blood-stained and fixed with a grin of  malice which would have held its own in the nethermost hell.

canine.word_example: The Count smiled, and as his lips ran back over his gums, the long, sharp,  canine teeth showed out strangely
canine.word_definition: one of the pointed teeth between the incisors and premolars

saturnine.word_example: Somehow his words and his look did not seem to accord, or else it was that his cast of face made his smile look malignant and  saturnine.

impalpable.word_example: As he swept his long arms, as though brushing aside some  impalpable obstacle, the wolves fell back and back further still.

repletion.word_example: He lay like a filthy leech, exhausted with his  repletion.

salutation.word_example: Having answered the Count’s  salutation, I turned to the glass again to see how I had been mistaken.
salutation.word_definition: an acknowledgment or expression of good will

graceful.word_example: My host, who stood on one side of the great fireplace, leaning against the stonework, made a  graceful wave of his hand to the table, and said: “I pray you, be seated and sup how you please. You will, I trust, excuse me that I do not join you; but I have dined already, and I do not sup.”

pallor.word_example: He was either dead or asleep, I could not say which—for the eyes were open and stony, but without the glassiness of death—and the cheeks had the warmth of life through all their  pallor; the lips were as red as ever.
pallor.word_definition: unnatural lack of color in the skin

stately.word_example: After a pause of a moment, he proceeded, in his  stately way, to the door, drew back the ponderous bolts, unhooked the heavy chains, and began to draw it open.
stately.word_definition: refined or imposing in manner or appearance

harsh.word_example: Somewhere high overhead, probably on the tower, I heard the voice of the Count calling in his  harsh, metallic whisper.

suave.word_example: Last night the Count asked me in the  suavest tones to write three letters, one saying that my work here was nearly done, and that I should start for home within a few days, another that I was starting on the next morning from the time of the letter, and the third that I had left the castle and arrived at Bistritz.
suave.word_definition: agreeable and courteous with a degree of sophistication

acumen.word_example: For a man who was never in the country, and who did not evidently do much in the way of business, his knowledge and  acumen were wonderful.

coarse.word_example: Hitherto I had noticed the backs of his hands as they lay on his knees in the firelight, and they had seemed rather white and fine; but seeing them now close to me, I could not but notice that they were rather  coarse—broad, with squat fingers.
coarse.word_definition: lacking refinement or cultivation or taste

aquiline.word_example: His face was a strong—a very strong— aquiline, with high bridge of the thin nose and peculiarly arched nostrils; with lofty domed forehead, and hair growing scantily round the temples but profusely elsewhere.
aquiline.word_definition: curved down like an eagle's beak

lurid.word_example: The red light in them was  lurid, as if the flames of hell-fire blazed behind them.
lurid.word_definition: shining with an unnatural red glow

satiate.word_example: This was the being I was helping to transfer to London, where, perhaps, for centuries to come he might, amongst its teeming millions,  satiate his lust for blood, and create a new and ever-widening circle of semi-demons to batten on the helpless.

semblance.word_example: What manner of man is this, or what manner of creature is it in the  semblance of man?
semblance.word_definition: an outward appearance that is deliberately misleading

vitality.word_example: The mouth, so far as I could see it under the heavy moustache, was fixed and rather cruel-looking, with peculiarly sharp white teeth; these protruded over the lips, whose remarkable ruddiness showed astonishing  vitality in a man of his years.
vitality.word_definition: a healthy capacity for vigorous activity

impulsive.word_example: The instant, however, that I had stepped over the threshold, he moved impulsively forward, and holding out his hand grasped mine with a strength which made me wince, an effect which was not lessened by the fact that it seemed as cold as ice—more like the hand of a dead than a living man.
impulsive.word_definition: characterized by undue haste and lack of thought

extraordinary.word_example: He petted and soothed them, and whispered something in their ears, as I have heard of horse-tamers doing, and with  extraordinary effect, for under his caresses they became quite manageable again, though they still trembled.
extraordinary.word_definition: highly unusual or exceptional or remarkable

intonation.word_example: The old man motioned me in with his right hand with a courtly gesture, saying in excellent English, but with a strange  intonation: “Welcome to my house! Enter freely and of your own will!”
intonation.word_definition: rise and fall of the voice pitch

prodigious.word_example: Then I descended from the side of the coach, as the calèche was close alongside, the driver helping me with a hand which caught my arm in a grip of steel; his strength must have been  prodigious.
prodigious.word_definition: great in size, force, extent, or degree

vein.word_example: We Szekelys have a right to be proud, for in our  veins flows the blood of many brave races who fought as the lion fights, for lordship.
vein.word_definition: a blood vessel that carries blood toward the heart

extreme.word_example: I find that the district he named is in the  extreme east of the country, just on the borders of three states, Transylvania, Moldavia and Bukovina, in the midst of the Carpathian mountains; one of the wildest and least known portions of Europe.

rage.word_example: As my eyes opened involuntarily I saw his strong hand grasp the slender neck of the fair woman and with giant’s power draw it back, the blue eyes transformed with fury, the white teeth champing with  rage, and the fair cheeks blazing red with passion.

diabolical.word_example: He smiled, such a soft, smooth,  diabolical smile that I knew there was some trick behind his smoothness.

imperious.word_example: How he came there, I know not, but I heard his voice raised in a tone of  imperious command, and looking towards the sound, saw him stand in the roadway.

mocking.word_example: There was a  mocking smile on the bloated face which seemed to drive me mad.

practical.word_example: He seemed thoroughly to understand, and went on to ask if there would be any  practical difficulty in having one man to attend, say, to banking, and another to look after shipping, in case local help were needed in a place far from the home of the banking solicitor.

repulsion.word_example: But my very feelings changed to  repulsion and terror when I saw the whole man slowly emerge from the window and begin to crawl down the castle wall over that dreadful abyss, face down with his cloak spreading out around him like great wings.

grasp.word_example: I saw the fingers and toes  grasp the corners of the stones, worn clear of the mortar by the stress of years, and by thus using every projection and inequality move downwards with considerable speed, just as a lizard moves along a wall.

hospitality.word_example: See!”—he must have looked at it—“one is from you, and to my friend Peter Hawkins; the other”—here he caught sight of the strange symbols as he opened the envelope, and the dark look came into his face, and his eyes blazed wickedly—“the other is a vile thing, an outrage upon friendship and  hospitality!
hospitality.word_definition: kindness in welcoming guests or strangers

gruesome.word_example: He finished his speech in a  gruesome way, for he motioned with his hands as if he were washing them.

courteous.word_example: The light and warmth and the Count’s  courteous welcome seemed to have dissipated all my doubts and fears.
courteous.word_definition: characterized by courtesy and gracious good manners

clad.word_example: Within, stood a tall old man, clean shaven save for a long white moustache, and  clad in black from head to foot, without a single speck of colour about him anywhere.

triumph.word_example: The last I saw of Count Dracula was his kissing his hand to me; with a red light of  triumph in his eyes, and with a smile that Judas in hell might be proud of.

\"Tess of the d'Urbervilles,\" Vocabular.list_brief_description: Thomas Hardy defended his main character with the subtitle "A Pure Woman," but this did not prevent Victorian censors from deleting some of the words in this li...

liberal.word_example: The letter was in the third person, and briefly informed Mrs Durbeyfield that her daughter's services would be useful to that lady in the management of her poultry-farm, that a comfortable room would be provided for her if she could come, and that the wages would be on a  liberal scale if they liked her.

rebuke.word_example: The struggles and wrangles of the lads for her hand in a jig were an amusement to her—no more; and when they became fierce she  rebuked them.

beneficent.word_example: However, Tess became humanely  beneficent towards the small ones, and to help them as much as possible she used, as soon as she left school, to lend a hand at haymaking or harvesting on neighbouring farms; or, by preference, at milking or butter-making processes, which she had learnt when her father had owned cows; and being deft-fingered it was a kind of work in which she excelled.

precarious.word_example: She had perceived that the horse was not the spirited one he sometimes rose, and felt no alarm on that score, though her seat was  precarious enough despite her tight hold of him.

respectable.word_example: "The maids don't think it  respectable to dance at The Flower-de-Luce," he explained.

esteem.word_example: Tess seemed for the moment really pleased to hear that she had won such high opinion from a stranger when, in her own  esteem, she had sunk so low.

reproachful.word_example: Even to her mother's gaze the girl's young features looked sadly out of place amid the alcoholic vapours which floated here as no unsuitable medium for wrinkled middle-age; and hardly was a  reproachful flash from Tess's dark eyes needed to make her father and mother rise from their seats, hastily finish their ale, and descend the stairs behind her, Mrs. Rolliver's caution following their footsteps.
reproachful.word_definition: expressing reproof especially as a corrective

spectacle.word_example: The two elder of the brothers were plainly not intending to linger more than a moment, but the  spectacle of a bevy of girls dancing without male partners seemed to amuse the third, and make him in no hurry to move on.
spectacle.word_definition: something or someone seen, especially a notable sight

adventitious.word_example: It was then that the ecstasy and the dream began, in which emotion was the matter of the universe, and matter but an  adventitious intrusion likely to hinder you from spinning where you wanted to spin.
adventitious.word_definition: associated by chance and not an integral part

onerous.word_example: Having at last taken her course Tess was less restless and abstracted, going about her business with some self-assurance in the thought of acquiring another horse for her father by an occupation which would not be  onerous.

descent.word_example: Don't you really know, Durbeyfield, that you are the lineal representative of the ancient and knightly family of the d'Urbervilles, who derive their  descent from Sir Pagan d'Urberville, that renowned knight who came from Normandy with William the Conqueror, as appears by Battle Abbey Roll?

equanimity.word_example: By the time the spot was reached she had recovered her  equanimity, and tapped her neighbour with her wand and talked as usual.

temptation.word_example: There—I said I would not come near you; and, in spite of such  temptation as never before fell to mortal man, I'll keep my word.
temptation.word_definition: something that entices or has the quality to entice

fascinated.word_example: A small minority, mainly strangers, would look long at her in casually passing by, and grow momentarily  fascinated by her freshness, and wonder if they would ever see her again: but to almost everybody she was a fine and picturesque country girl, and no more.
fascinated.word_definition: having your attention fixated as though by a spell

coarse.word_example: Why it was that upon this beautiful feminine tissue, sensitive as gossamer, and practically blank as snow as yet, there should have been traced such a  coarse pattern as it was doomed to receive; why so often the  coarse appropriates the finer thus, the wrong man the woman, the wrong woman the man, many thousand years of analytical philosophy have failed to explain to our sense of order.
coarse.word_definition: lacking refinement or cultivation or taste

proffer.word_example: At almost any other moment of her life she would have refused such  proffered aid and company, as she had refused them several times before; and now the loneliness would not of itself have forced her to do otherwise.

vicissitude.word_example: His own investigations had begun on a day in the preceding spring when, having been engaged in tracing the  vicissitudes of the d'Urberville family, he had observed Durbeyfield's name on his waggon, and had thereupon been led to make inquiries about his father and grandfather till he had no doubt on the subject.
vicissitude.word_definition: a variation in circumstances or fortune

unconscionable.word_example: Thus they sidled slowly onward till it struck her they had been advancing for an  unconscionable time—far longer than was usually occupied by the short journey from Chaseborough, even at this walking pace, and that they were no longer on hard road, but in a mere trackway.
unconscionable.word_definition: lacking a sense of right conduct

coiffure.word_example: Then she put upon her the white frock that Tess had worn at the club-walking, the airy fulness of which, supplementing her enlarged  coiffure, imparted to her developing figure an amplitude which belied her age, and might cause her to be estimated as a woman when she was not much more than a child.

zest.word_example: She remained with her comrades till dusk, and participated with a certain  zest in the dancing; though, being heart-whole as yet, she enjoyed treading a measure purely for its own sake; little divining when she saw "the soft torments, the bitter sweets, the pleasing pains, and the agreeable distresses" of those girls who had been wooed and won, what she herself was capable of in that kind.

lineament.word_example: Pedigree, ancestral skeletons, monumental record, the d'Urberville  lineaments, did not help Tess in her life's battle as yet, even to the extent of attracting to her a dancing-partner over the heads of the commonest peasantry.
lineament.word_definition: the characteristic parts of a person's face

deferential.word_example: The oppressive sense of the harm she had done led Tess to be more  deferential than she might otherwise have been to the maternal wish; but she could not understand why her mother should find such satisfaction in contemplating an enterprise of, to her, such doubtful profit.
deferential.word_definition: showing courteous regard for people's feelings

negotiate.word_example: As there were no men in the company, the girls danced at first with each other, but when the hour for the close of labour drew on, the masculine inhabitants of the village, together with other idlers and pedestrians, gathered round the spot, and appeared inclined to  negotiate for a partner.
negotiate.word_definition: discuss the terms of an arrangement

trepidation.word_example: Tess thought this was the mansion itself till, passing through the side wicket with some  trepidation, and onward to a point at which the drive took a turn, the house proper stood in full view.
trepidation.word_definition: a feeling of alarm or dread

animus.word_example: Several other woman also chimed in, with an  animus which none of them would have been so fatuous as to show but for the rollicking evening they had passed.
animus.word_definition: a feeling of ill will arousing active hostility

burden.word_example: Every day seemed to throw upon her young shoulders more of the family  burdens, and that Tess should be the representative of the Durbeyfields at the d'Urberville mansion came as a thing of course.

titter.word_example: The clubbists  tittered, except the girl called Tess—in whom a slow heat seemed to rise at the sense that her father was making himself foolish in their eyes.

prominent.word_example: Tess turned the subject by saying what was far more  prominent in her own mind at the moment than thoughts of her ancestry—"I am afraid father won't be able to take the journey with the beehives to-morrow so early."
prominent.word_definition: having a quality that thrusts itself into attention

inexorable.word_example: He was  inexorable, and she sat still, and d'Urberville gave her the kiss of mastery.
inexorable.word_definition: not to be placated or appeased or moved by entreaty

pliable.word_example: But she was more  pliable under his hands than a mere companionship would have made her, owing to her unavoidable dependence upon his mother, and, through that lady's comparative helplessness, upon him.
pliable.word_definition: susceptible to being led or directed

covet.word_example: Had she perceived this meeting's import she might have asked why she was doomed to be seen and  coveted that day by the wrong man, and not by some other man, the right and desired one in all respects—as nearly as humanity can supply the right and desired; yet to him who amongst her acquaintance might have approximated to this kind, she was but a transient impression, half forgotten.

accomplishment.word_example: Tess could whistle like most other country-girls, though the  accomplishment was one which she did not care to profess in genteel company.
accomplishment.word_definition: an ability that has been acquired by training

fatalistic.word_example: As Tess's own people down in those retreats are never tired of saying among each other in their  fatalistic way: "It was to be."
fatalistic.word_definition: accepting that everything that happens is inevitable

modest.word_example: She was so  modest, so expressive, she had looked so soft in her thin white gown that he felt he had acted stupidly.

rehabilitation.word_example: How could she face her parents, get back her box, and disconcert the whole scheme for the  rehabilitation of her family on such sentimental grounds?

stagger.word_example: Tess soon perceived as she walked in the flock, sometimes with this one, sometimes with that, that the fresh night air was producing staggerings and serpentine courses among the men who had partaken too freely; some of the more careless women also were wandering in their gait
stagger.word_definition: walk as if unable to control one's movements

prostrate.word_example: "Sir John d'Urberville—that's who I am," continued the  prostrate man.
prostrate.word_definition: stretched out and lying at full length along the ground

vexation.word_example: But he persisted in his demand, and at last, to get rid of him, she did put up her lips as directed for producing a clear note; laughing distressfully, however, and then blushing with  vexation that she had laughed.
vexation.word_definition: anger produced by some annoying irritation

excursion.word_example: The two women valiantly disguised these forced  excursions and countermarches as well as they could from Durbeyfield, their cause, and from Abraham, and from themselves; and so they approached by degrees their own door, the head of the family bursting suddenly into his former refrain as he drew near, as if to fortify his soul at sight of the smallness of his present residence

vituperation.word_example: The rather too inclusive speech brought down a torrent of  vituperation from other quarters upon fair Tess's unlucky head, particularly from the Queen of Diamonds, who having stood in the relations to d'Urberville that Car had also been suspected of, united with the latter against the common enemy.
vituperation.word_definition: abusive or venomous language to express blame or censure

antic.word_example: Fear not, my lord; we can contain ourselves,
antic.word_definition: a ludicrous or grotesque act done for fun and amusement

office.word_example: Take him up gently, and to bed with him;
office.word_definition: activities assigned to or expected of a person or group

dulcet.word_example: Procure me music ready when he wakes,

dispatch.word_example: See this dispatch'd with all the haste thou canst

esteem.word_example: And then with kind embracements, tempting kisses,

jest.word_example: Then take him up, and manage well the  jest

obeisance.word_example: Sirrah, go you to Bartholomew my page,
obeisance.word_definition: bending the head or body in reverence or submission

humor.word_description: Nowadays, humor is usually connected to laughter. While the lord might be laughing in his heart, he is outwardly keeping a straight and concerned face in order to play a joke on the tinker. Here, "idle humor" refers to a bodily fluid that, in excess, causes madness, but the phrase could be a pun that makes fun of the joke ("idle" can mean "silly or trivial"). There could also be a pun in "foul spirit" ("spirit" can refer to alcohol), since the drunken tinker behaves badly.
humor.word_example: Heaven cease this idle humour in your honour!
humor.word_definition: fluid in the body believed to determine your emotional state

homage.word_example: I long to hear him call the drunkard 'husband';

unfathomable.word_description: The Old English root of "fathom" refers to the "length of the outstretched arm" which is about six feet. Thus, "unfathomable" also means "resembling an abyss in depth; so deep as to be immeasurable." This is suggested by preceding descriptions of the millions of miles of the material universe. As a philosopher presenting astronomical observations, the narrator is concerned with both the literal and figurative meanings of the adjective.
unfathomable.word_example: Near it in the field, I remember, were three faint points of light, three telescopic stars infinitely remote, and all around it was the  unfathomable darkness of empty space.

incessant.word_example: The intellectual side of man already admits that life is an  incessant struggle for existence, and it would seem that this too is the belief of the minds upon Mars.
incessant.word_definition: uninterrupted in time and indefinitely long continuing

perceptive.word_description: The adjective also means "having the ability to understand," which usually applies to the narrator. Here, his focus is on the perceptive power of his eyes. This is emphasized by the word "erethism" ("an abnormally high degree of sensitivity to stimulation") and this description: "I remember that dinner table with extraordinary vividness even now. My dear wife's sweet anxious face peering at me from under the pink lamp shade, the white cloth with its silver and glass table furniture."
perceptive.word_example: The intense excitement of the events had no doubt left my  perceptive powers in a state of erethism.
perceptive.word_definition: of or relating to awareness via the senses

design.word_description: The mention of shape and color connects to the definition of "design" as "the way something is arranged or organized." This contemplation of physical design leads the astronomer to consider that the cylinder's arrival is due to some intelligent design (the debate between intelligent design and evolution would've been on the minds of the author, his philosophical narrator, and 19th century readers).
design.word_example: He remained standing at the edge of the pit that the Thing had made for itself, staring at its strange appearance, astonished chiefly at its unusual shape and colour, and dimly perceiving even then some evidence of  design in its arrival.
design.word_definition: an anticipated outcome that is intended

occur.word_example: A stirring noise within its cylinder he ascribed to the unequal cooling of its surface; for at that time it had not  occurred to him that it might be hollow.

sensible.word_example: There was no  sensible transition from one state of mind to the other.

steadfast.word_example: Two large dark-coloured eyes were regarding me steadfastly.
steadfast.word_definition: marked by firm determination or resolution; not shakable

ruthless.word_example: And before we judge of them too harshly we must remember what  ruthless and utter destruction our own species has wrought, not only upon animals, such as the vanished bison and the dodo, but upon its inferior races.

confounded.word_description: The adjective also means "odious, detestable, damned." Angry at the crowd (one of whom had fallen into the pit) who's interfering with the examination of the strange cylinder, the astronomer can be described by the chosen definition while he curses the thing (and the idiots).
confounded.word_example: "I say!" said Ogilvy; "help keep these idiots back. We don't know what's in the  confounded thing, you know!"
confounded.word_definition: perplexed by many conflicting situations or statements

dumbfounded.word_example: All this had happened with such swiftness that I had stood motionless,  dumbfounded and dazzled by the flashes of light.
dumbfounded.word_definition: as if rendered speechless with astonishment and surprise

intellect.word_description: "Intellect" comes from the past participle of the Latin verb "intelligere" while "intelligence" comes from the present participle. The two nouns are synonymous, except that "intellect" can refer to a single person and does not usually connect to enemies. But as the example sentence suggests, the Martians are our enemies because of their intellects.
intellect.word_example: Yet across the gulf of space, minds that are to our minds as ours are to those of the beasts that perish,  intellects vast and cool and unsympathetic, regarded this earth with envious eyes, and slowly and surely drew their plans against us.

consultation.word_example: There had been a hasty  consultation, and since the Martians were evidently, in spite of their repulsive forms, intelligent creatures, it had been resolved to show them, by approaching them with signals, that we too were intelligent.
consultation.word_definition: a meeting to discuss a particular question or topic

rational.word_example: The fear I felt was no  rational fear, but a panic terror not only of the Martians, but of the dusk and stillness all about me.
rational.word_definition: consistent with or based on or using reason

persuasion.word_example: I remember I felt an extraordinary  persuasion that I was being played with, that presently, when I was upon the very verge of safety, this mysterious death--as swift as the passage of light--would leap after me from the pit about the cylinder and strike me down.

perplexed.word_definition: full of difficulty or confusion or bewilderment

fascination.word_example: After the glimpse I had had of the Martians emerging from the cylinder in which they had come to the earth from their planet, a kind of  fascination paralysed my actions.
fascination.word_definition: the state of being intensely interested

perceive.word_example: It required a certain amount of scientific education to  perceive that the grey scale of the Thing was no common oxide, that the yellowish-white metal that gleamed in the crack between the lid and the cylinder had an unfamiliar hue.
perceive.word_definition: to become aware of through the senses

ignorance.word_example: Yet the next day there was nothing of this in the papers except a little note in the Daily Telegraph, and the world went in  ignorance of one of the gravest dangers that ever threatened the human race.
ignorance.word_definition: the lack of knowledge or education

inarticulate.word_example: I heard  inarticulate exclamations on all sides.
inarticulate.word_definition: without or deprived of the use of speech or words

hypothesis.word_example: It must be, if the nebular  hypothesis has any truth, older than our world; and long before this earth ceased to be molten, life upon its surface must have begun its course.
hypothesis.word_definition: a proposal intended to explain certain facts or observations

fancy.word_example: He  fancied even then that the cooling of the body might account for this, but what disturbed that idea was the fact that the ash was falling only from the end of the cylinder.
fancy.word_definition: imagine; conceive of; see in one's mind

necessity.word_example: The immediate pressure of  necessity has brightened their intellects, enlarged their powers, and hardened their hearts.
necessity.word_definition: the condition of being essential or indispensable

inconceivable.word_example: At times I suffer from the strangest sense of detachment from myself and the world about me; I seem to watch it all from the outside, from somewhere inconceivably remote, out of time, out of space, out of the stress and tragedy of it all.

intense.word_example: The peculiar V-shaped mouth with its pointed upper lip, the absence of brow ridges, the absence of a chin beneath the wedgelike lower lip, the incessant quivering of this mouth, the Gorgon groups of tentacles, the tumultuous breathing of the lungs in a strange atmosphere, the evident heaviness and painfulness of movement due to the greater gravitational energy of the earth--above all, the extraordinary intensity of the immense eyes--were at once vital,  intense, inhuman, crippled and monstrous.
intense.word_definition: possessing a distinctive feature to a heightened degree

interpret.word_example: Men like Schiaparelli watched the red planet--it is odd, by-the-bye, that for countless centuries Mars has been the star of war--but failed to  interpret the fluctuating appearances of the markings they mapped so well.

possess.word_example: And, in the second place, we all overlooked the fact that such mechanical intelligence as the Martian  possessed was quite able to dispense with muscular exertion at a pinch.
possess.word_definition: have as an attribute, knowledge, or skill

palpitate.word_example: As Mars approached opposition, Lavelle of Java set the wires of the astronomical exchange  palpitating with the amazing intelligence of a huge outbreak of incandescent gas upon the planet.

evident.word_example: It was only when I got thus close to it that the strangeness of this object was at all  evident to me.
evident.word_definition: clearly revealed to the mind or the senses or judgment

contemplate.word_example: I was very glad to do as he asked, and so become one of the privileged spectators within the  contemplated enclosure.
contemplate.word_definition: look at thoughtfully; observe deep in thought

anticipate.word_example: Stent and Ogilvy,  anticipating some possibilities of a collision, had telegraphed from Horsell to the barracks as soon as the Martians emerged, for the help of a company of soldiers to protect these strange creatures from violence.
anticipate.word_definition: regard something as probable or likely

indisputable.word_example: The invigorating influences of this excess of oxygen upon the Martians  indisputably did much to counterbalance the increased weight of their bodies.
indisputable.word_definition: not open to question; obviously true

novelty.word_example: You may imagine the young people brushed up after the labours of the day, and making this  novelty, as they would make any  novelty, the excuse for walking together and enjoying a trivial flirtation.
novelty.word_definition: originality by virtue of being new and surprising

\"The War of the Worlds,\" Vocabulary fr.list_detailed_description: Reporting on a Martian invasion, these words from the narrator created by H.G. Wells gripped readers' imaginations in terrifying and inspiring ways.

\"The Sun Is Also a Star,\" Vocabulary f.list_brief_description: In one of the most popular and highly praised YA novels of 2016, Nicola Yoon tells the story of two teens who meet and fall in love over the course of a single ...

patois.word_example: Maybe you've heard the word irie before. Maybe you’ve traveled to Jamaica and know that it has some roots in the Jamaican dialect,  patois.
patois.word_definition: a regional dialect of a language

decency.word_example: Secretly, in their heart of hearts, almost everyone believes that there’s some meaning, some willfulness to life. Fairness. Basic  decency. Good things happen to good people. Bad things only happen to bad people.
decency.word_definition: the quality of conforming to rules of propriety and morality

actuarial.word_example: He has  actuarial tables in his mind. He knows the cost of a human life lost in an airplane crash, a car accident, a mining disaster. He knows these things because he once worked in insurance. It was his job to price the unwanted and unexpected.
actuarial.word_definition: relating to statistics to calculate insurance premiums

navigate.word_example: It even has instructions on how to find Polaris and  navigate your way by stars in case you get lost.
navigate.word_definition: direct and plot the path and position of a conveyance

random.word_example: “Something temporary and not at all measurable. People just want to believe. Otherwise they would have to admit that life is just a  random series of good and bad things that happen until one day you die.”
random.word_definition: lacking any definite plan or order or purpose

improbable.word_example: Something strange and  improbable would happen so that the impossible couldn’t.
improbable.word_definition: having a chance of occurring too low to inspire belief

optimistic.word_example: Bev’s always been relentlessly  optimistic, even in the face of dire odds.
optimistic.word_definition: hopeful that the best will happen in the future

dictate.word_example: Since I’m letting the universe  dictate my life on this Final Day of Childhood, I don’t bother waiting for another train to take me to Thirty-Fourth Street.

subtle.word_example: I look left and right. Still no Sign. I’m looking for something  subtle, along the lines of a long-haired man turning water into wine and holding a placard proclaiming himself to be Jesus Christ, Our Lord and Savior.
subtle.word_definition: difficult to detect or grasp by the mind or analyze

extinction.word_example: If you want to make an apple pie from nothing at all, you have to start with the Big Bang and expanding universes, neutrons, ions, atoms, black holes, suns, moons, ocean tides, the Milky Way, Earth, evolution, dinosaurs, extinction-level events, platypuses, Homo erectus, Cro-Magnon man, etc.

constellation.word_example: It’s huge—actually eight posters that I taped together—and shows all the major stars,  constellations, and sections of the Milky Way visible from the Northern Hemisphere.
constellation.word_definition: a configuration of stars as seen from the earth

prosperity.word_example: For most immigrants, moving to the new country is an act of faith. Even if you’ve heard stories of safety, opportunity, and  prosperity, it’s still a leap to remove yourself from your own language, people, and country.
prosperity.word_definition: the condition of having good fortune

paradox.word_example: “And we’re ignoring the grandfather  paradox?” she asks.

destiny.word_example: Local Teen Accepts  Destiny, Agrees to Become Doctor
destiny.word_definition: the circumstances or condition to which someone is fated

sentiment.word_example: Things happen for a reason, Tasha. I don’t believe that  sentiment, but still, there has to be a logical explanation for the horribleness of this day.

strategy.word_example: I want to tell him that maybe he shouldn’t leave everything up to God and that hoping against hope is not a life  strategy, but that would mean I would have to talk to him, and I don’t want to talk to him.
strategy.word_definition: an elaborate and systematic plan of action

content.word_example: Everything is all right between you and your god, and therefore between you and the world. To be irie is to be in a high and  content spiritual place. In the word, you hear the invention of religion itself.
content.word_definition: satisfied or showing satisfaction with things as they are

copacetic.word_example: Anyone looking in at us from the outside would think things are  copacetic.

futile.word_example: My mom says it’s time for me to give up now, and that what I’m doing is  futile.

betray.word_example: But before that, before he becomes a politician and marries well, before he changes his name to Charles Bay, before he  betrays his good wife and constituents at every turn, before too much money and success and much too much of getting everything that he wants, he will do a good and selfless thing for his brother.
betray.word_definition: disappoint, abandon, or prove undependable to

satellite.word_example: It seems like such a long time ago when I thought the world of him. He was some exotic planet and I was his favorite  satellite. But he’s no planet, just the final fading light of an already dead star.
satellite.word_definition: any celestial body orbiting around a planet or star

fate.word_example: Today is my last chance to try to convince someone—or  fate—to help me find a way to stay in America.
fate.word_definition: the ultimate agency predetermining the course of events

banter.word_example: He is classically handsome; debonair, even. Watching him stand there in his suit, I can picture him in a black-and-white Hollywood romantic comedy trading witty  banter with his heroine.

impress.word_example: I am clearly not meant to  impress this girl.
impress.word_definition: have an emotional or cognitive impact upon

quota.word_example: Her face dares me to ask her more, but I’ve reached my  quota of daring things (1=following cute girl, 2=yelling at ex-boyfriend of cute girl, 3=saving life of cute girl, 4=asking out cute girl) for the day.

deja vu.word_example: I get a sudden sense of  deja vu. I’ve been here before. I’ve noticed those bright eyes and that smile. I’ve even had this conversation.
deja vu.word_definition: the experience of thinking a new situation already occurred

nihilism.word_example: Instead of pushing him away, my  nihilism is only making him more comfortable.
nihilism.word_definition: the delusion that things do not exist

reversal.word_example: My whole life it’s been the opposite. Why can’t you be more like your brother? This  Reversal of Fortune is not good for either of us.

compass.word_example: Names are powerful things. They act as an identity marker and a kind of map, locating you in time and geography. More than that, they can be a  compass.

anonymous.word_example: To her I’m just another  anonymous face, another applicant, another someone who wants something from America.
anonymous.word_definition: having no known name or identity or known source

inevitable.word_example: It doesn’t mean love at first sight. It’s closer to love at second sight. It’s the feeling when you meet someone that you’re going to fall in love with them. Maybe you don’t love them right away, but it’s  inevitable that you will.
inevitable.word_definition: incapable of being avoided or prevented

interaction.word_example: Every  interaction with these applicants saves her life just a little.

rejection.word_example: And  rejection was not an easy thing. To be an actor you’re supposed to have thick skin, but Samuel’s skin was never thick enough.  Rejection was like sandpaper.
rejection.word_definition: the state of being turned down

romantic.word_example: Besides the fact that I’m being deported today, I am really not a girl to fall in love with. For one thing, I don’t like temporary, nonprovable things, and  romantic love is both temporary and nonprovable.

resign.word_example: Resigned Local Takes Westbound 7 Train to Childhood's End

vortex.word_example: Local Teen Trapped in Parental  Vortex of Expectation and Disappointment, Doesn’t Expect to Be Rescued
vortex.word_definition: a powerful circular current of water

infinitesimal.word_example: Like hydrogen-7 or lithium-5 or boron-7, love has an  infinitesimally small half-life that decays to nothing.

logic.word_example: Instead of being ruled by  logic, we are ruled by emotions.

salvation.word_example: The conductor loves the notion that you can be made anew, free of sin and therefore worthy of love and  salvation.
salvation.word_definition: the act of delivering from sin or saving from evil

cynic.word_example: My dad says he doesn’t know where my cynicism comes from, but I’m not a  cynic. I am a realist. It’s better to see life as it is, not as you wish it to be. Things don’t happen for a reason. They just happen.
cynic.word_definition: someone who is critical of the motives of others

\"The Sun Is Also a Star,\" Vocabulary f.list_detailed_description: In one of the most popular and highly praised YA novels of 2016, Nicola Yoon tells the story of two teens who meet and fall in love over the course of a single day in New York City. Learn these words and see why this book shines.

\"The Last Olympian,\" Vocabulary from C.list_brief_description: In the final book of Rick Riordan's Olympians series, Percy is nearly 16 and faced with choices that will affect not only himself but his entire world. Learn th...

bearing.word_example: Being the son of Poseidon and all, I have perfect  bearings at sea. Don’t ask me how, but I could tell we were at 40.19° North, 71.90° West, making eighteen knots, which meant the ship would arrive in New York Harbor by dawn. This would be our only chance to stop it.
bearing.word_definition: the direction or path along which something moves or lies

retrieve.word_example: I was empty-handed. Riptide, being magic, would appear in my pocket sooner or later, but for now it was stuck somewhere under the wreckage of the crab, and I had no time to  retrieve it.
retrieve.word_definition: get or find back; recover the use of

bicker.word_example: “We’re fighting for our lives,” I said, “and they’re  bickering about some stupid chariot.”

improvise.word_example: The whole idea had been to get in and out without being spotted. But we were going to have to  improvise.
improvise.word_definition: manage in a makeshift way; do with whatever is at hand

irresponsible.word_example: Now, I know you're thinking, Wow, that was really  irresponsible of him, blah, blah, blah, but Paul knows me pretty well.
irresponsible.word_definition: showing lack of care for consequences

mission.word_example: Still, something big was supposed to go down any day now. I was “on call” for a  mission.
mission.word_definition: a special assignment that is given to a person or group

revitalize.word_example: The water  revitalized me, breaking the time spell, and I lunged forward.

sap.word_example: The wound in my arm was  sapping my ability to think, but I muttered, “Communication device ... spy at camp.”

literally.word_example: “Percy,” Annabeth said. "You know prophecies always have double meanings. It might not  literally mean you die."
literally.word_definition: in a sense limited to explicit meaning

decision.word_example: I don’t know what your final  decision will be, but your fight lies in the world above.
decision.word_definition: the act of making up your mind about something

jeopardize.word_example: Then I did something I hadn’t planned on. It was probably stupid. It definitely  jeopardized our mission, but I couldn’t help it.

strategist.word_example: You’re the best  strategist I know. If you were Kronos planning this war, what would you do next?
strategist.word_definition: an expert in systematic plans of action

eventually.word_example: A voice in my head said: I have to fight him  eventually. Why not now?
eventually.word_definition: after an unspecified period of time or a long delay

naive.word_example: As I said it, I knew it was a  naive hope. We might blow up his ship and disintegrate his monsters, but a Titan lord wouldn’t be so easy to kill.

blame.word_example: Percy, Beckendorf chose a heroic death. You bear no  blame for that.
blame.word_definition: a reproach for some lapse or misdeed

depressing.word_example: There were messages from demigods, nature spirits, and satyrs all around the country, writing about the latest monster activity. They were pretty  depressing, and my ADHD brain did not like concentrating on  depressing stuff.
depressing.word_definition: causing sad feelings of gloom and inadequacy

pressure.word_example: I’d been hearing about the “Great Prophecy" for years, but nobody would ever tell me the whole thing. All I knew was that I was supposed to make a decision that would decide the fate of the world—but no  pressure.
pressure.word_definition: an oppressive condition of physical or mental distress

warn.word_example: I thought about my dream: the Titans discussing the explosion as if it didn’t matter, Nico di Angelo  warning me that I would never beat Kronos without following his plan—a dangerous idea I'd been avoiding for more than a year.
warn.word_definition: notify of danger, potential harm, or risk

annihilate.word_example: “Obliterate,” Annabeth said. “ Annihilate. Turn to rubble.”

phase.word_example: Last summer, before Luke had turned into Kronos and everything went sour, there had been a few times when I thought maybe ... well, that we might get past the strangle-each-other  phase.
phase.word_definition: any distinct time period in a sequence of events

reap.word_example: “And see the world in endless sleep,

identity.word_example: I wasn’t just losing blood. I could feel my strength, my will, my  identity draining away.
identity.word_definition: the characteristics by which a thing or person is known

distraction.word_example: If I’d wanted to create a  distraction, I'd succeeded, but this was not where I wanted to fight.
distraction.word_definition: drawing someone's attention away from something

heinous.word_example: But since we both hated our jobs, we decided to do them together so it wouldn't be so  heinous.

substance.word_example: He tossed me a jar of thick green liquid—Greek fire, one of the most dangerous magical  substances in the world.
substance.word_definition: a particular kind of matter with uniform properties

omen.word_example: The thing is, they’re never just dreams. They’ve got to be visions,  omens, and all that other mystical stuff that makes my brain hurt.
omen.word_definition: a sign of a thing about to happen

odds.word_example: "A half-blood of the eldest gods .. . shall reach sixteen against all  odds .. .”
odds.word_definition: the likelihood of a thing occurring

guilty.word_example: It dawned on me that she knew I’d been hanging out with Rachel, and I felt  guilty. Then I felt angry that I felt  guilty. I was allowed to have friends outside camp, right? It wasn’t like ...

according.word_example: According to that big prophecy, I was supposed to make a choice that saved or destroyed the world when I was sixteen.

detonate.word_example: We’d jump into the sea. My water powers would protect us both, and we’d  detonate the charges from a quarter mile away.
detonate.word_definition: cause to burst with a violent release of energy

heed.word_example: “Percy, there were only a few demigod warriors aboard that ship, and they all chose to battle for Kronos. Perhaps some  heeded your warning and escaped. If they did not... they chose their path.”

invitation.word_example: “So.” Rachel smiled at me. “About that  invitation.”
invitation.word_definition: a request to be present or take part in something

aid.word_example: I willed the ocean currents to  aid me. Water swirled around me, and I shot toward the surface at speeds that would’ve caused any normal human to pop like a balloon.
aid.word_definition: give help or assistance; be of service

raze.word_definition: tear down so as to make flat with the ground

essential.word_example: Then he threw me another  essential tool of demigod heroes—duct tape.

\"The Last Olympian,\" Vocabulary from C.list_detailed_description: In the final book of Rick Riordan's Olympians series, Percy is nearly 16 and faced with choices that will affect not only himself but his entire world. Learn these words from Percy's final adventure.
